Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

leads.lead_text: Ligules of ray florets 0.4–1 mm long
Ligules of ray florets 1.8–3.8 mm long

Cypselas oblanceolate, smooth on both faces and edges, light or yellowish brown; cypsela glands confined to the beak and near carpopodium on both dorsal and ventral edges; leaves and scapes firmly attached to stem and/or rootstock

Cypselas obliquely obovate, transversely wrinkled on both faces and edges, dark reddish brown; cypsela glands on the dorsal edge densely and continuously distributed from beak to carpopodium; leaves and scapes usually readily detached from rootstock

Roots tuberous and fleshy, bunched; rhizomes short; stem absent or very short (leaves in basal rosette); cypsela glands confined to the beak and adjacent upper dorsal edge; cypselas usually with 1–5 hairs at         base

Roots  fibrous and wiry, not bunched, rhizomes spreading; stem short or often elongated (leaves alternate along stem), achene glands on the dorsal edge densely and continuously distributed from beak to   carpopodium; cypselas without basal hairs
Scape glabrous or with a few appressed to antrorse hairs; the apex of involucral bracts obtuse
Scape hairs retrorse to patent; involucral bracts more or less subulate and finely pointed
Leaf margins usually obtusely serrate; scape with eglandular hairs only; cypsela glands usually confined to dorsal edge from beak to carpopodium

Leaf margins sinuate to undulate; scape with eglandular hairs and shorter glandular hairs; cypsela glands extend all along ventral and dorsal edges from beak to carpopodium and often on the basal and   distal portions of both faces
